comments.author: palladia
comments.body:
PS DSC for Linux Python scripts have been converted to cmdlets, and these cmdlets reside as a PS module (Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Omi).  This is tested and checked-in.

The work on MI to create MOF file is a bit different.  MOF files are used as input to the DSC Python scripts (and the new cmdlets).  I was able to get some MOF samples from J. Kordich, to test my cmdlets.

That’s not true.  The new Omi cmdlets all return PS “objects”, or array of “objects”.  Some of these objects may have embedded XML, so that they look kind of long, but the cmdlets themselves do return PS objects.

The instances they return cannot currently be used how users would expect, e.g. `Instance.OperatingSystem`. If that's no longer the case, please update the test.

I don't think we can consider this closed until the return result is more than just a string. An instance of a class should map to a PowerShell object that can be queried.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
The way the object is encoded is incorrect. Take a look at the `Name`, `Type`, and `Value` members of the object. They're arrays of strings of the names, types, and values of the data within the object, but are completely disassociated from each other.

But that's going the wrong direction. To be useful, it would contains objects that each have an associated `Name`, `Type`, and `Value`, such that `$instance.$name` returns that `$name`'s `$value`.

Perhaps this is an issue with the XML itself, but I imagine we're just deserializing it going the wrong direction (that is to say, creating objects across columns rather than rows).

This is hard to explain over text.
